Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of High-Flow Nasal Oxygen in High-Risk Cardiac Surgical Patients

Background: This study assessed the efficacy of high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO) in reducing hospital length of stay compared to standard oxygen therapy in cardiac surgical patients at high risk for postoperative pulmonary complications.

Methods: Conducted at a single centre, 100 adult patients scheduled for elective cardiac surgery were randomised 1:1 to receive HFNO (n=51) or standard oxygen therapy (n=49). Eligibility criteria included COPD, asthma, recent lower respiratory tract infection, BMI ≥35 kg/m², or heavy smoking. The primary outcome was hospital length of stay, measured from surgery to discharge. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment via a centralised online system. Surgical and nursing teams responsible for discharge were blinded to group allocation.

Results: Median hospital length of stay was 7 days (IQR 6–9) in the HFNO group and 9 days (IQR 7–16) in the standard group (p=0.012). The geometric mean hospital stay was 29% lower in the HFNO group (95% CI 11–44%, p=0.004). ICU re-admissions were significantly fewer in the HFNO group (1/49) compared to the standard group (7/45; p=0.026). No significant adverse events were reported in either group.

Interpretation: HFNO significantly reduced hospital length of stay and ICU re-admissions in high-risk cardiac surgical patients compared to standard oxygen therapy. These findings suggest that HFNO may offer clinical and economic benefits in this patient population.
